quiz.text: Three balls are drawn randomly from bag A. What is the probability that each drawn ball is of different colour?
options: 9/35
7/43
9/50
1/13
None of these

quiz.text: Two balls are drawn from bag C. What is the probability that both balls are of white colour?
options: 1/19
2/19
3/19
4/19
5/19

quiz.text: Four balls are drawn from bag B. What is the probability that two are saffron, one is white and one is green in colour?
options: 219/1771
221/1771
216/1771
214/1771
None of these

quiz.text: What is the number of white balls in bag B?
options: 9
10
6
12
7

quiz.text: Two balls are drawn from bag C. What is the probability of getting a Saffron and a white ball?
options: 11/19
14/19
8/19
5/19
None of these

quiz.text: A bag contains certain number of balls in which 26 balls are red and rest balls are green. Two balls are randomly drawn from the bag; the probability that a green ball and a red ball is drawn is 7/15. Find the total number of balls in the bag.
options: 30
40
45
50
55

quiz.text: There are 10 marigold flowers (5 orange & 5 yellow). In how many ways, 5 flowers can be selected such that there are at-least 3 orange marigold flowers?
options: 94
165
126
201
146

quiz.text: A bag contains 5 red, ‘x’ green and 3 blue balls. If two balls are drawn from the bag randomly, then the probability of getting a red and a green ball is 3/11. Find the value of x.
options: 2
4
5
3
6

quiz.text: How many four letter words having at most three consonants and at least 1 vowel can be formed by using the letters of the word “CASTLIEY”?
options: 65
360
720
1560
None of these

quiz.text: There 5 poetry books, 8 biographies and 3 fiction books in a box. 8 books are drawn from the box at random. Find the probability of drawing 2 poetry books, 3 biographies and 3 fictions from the box.
options: 80/211
56/1287
68/155
61/145
None of these

quiz.text: Five men and six women are sitting in a row.   Quantity-I: If two people are picked at random, what’s the probability that both are women? Quantity-II: What is the probability that two particular men never sit together?
options: Quantity-I > Quantity-II
Quantity-I ≤ Quantity-II
Quantity-I < Quantity-II
Quantity-I = Quantity-II or No relation
Quantity-I ≥ Quantity-II

quiz.text: Quantity I: In how many ways can the letters of the word ‘ARRANGE’ be arranged such that all the vowels are always together? Quantity-II: In how many ways can a team of 9 students be selected from a group of 12 students?
options: Quantity-I ≥ Quantity-II
Quantity-I < Quantity-II
Quantity-I ≤ Quantity-II
Quantity-I = Quantity-II or No relation
Quantity-I > Quantity-II

quiz.text: Quantity-I: Find the number of words with or without meaning that can be formed with the letters of the word “ARIEL” such that all vowels are together. Quantity-II: A group has 5 men and 4 women. Find the number of ways of picking a team of 6 members from the group such that there are at least 4 men in the team.
options: Quantity-I ≤ Quantity-II
Quantity-I < Quantity-II
Quantity-I > Quantity-II
Quantity-I = Quantity-II or No relation
Quantity-I ≥ Quantity-II

quiz.text: Quantity-I: In how many ways, a team of 2 boys and 3 girls can be selected from a group of 8 boys and 10 girls? Quantity-II: A 5 members committee is to be selected from a group of 6 men and 12 women. In how many ways a committee having at least 4 women can be selected?
options: Quantity-I > Quantity-II
Quantity-I < Quantity-II
Quantity-I ≤ Quantity-II
Quantity-I = Quantity-II or No relation
Quantity-I ≥ Quantity-II

quiz.text: Quantity-I: A bag contains 8 red and 4 black balls. Find the probability of drawing 2 red balls from the bag. Quantity-II: A box contains 12 green ball and 8 yellow balls. Find the probability of drawing 3 green balls from the box.
options: Quantity-I > Quantity-II
Quantity-I < Quantity-II
Quantity-I ≤ Quantity-II
Quantity-I = Quantity-II or No relation
Quantity-I ≥ Quantity-II

quiz.text: A bag contains red, blue and green balls. Numbers of red and green balls in the bag are 20% and 40% respectively less than the number of blue balls in the bag. Find the total number of balls in the bag.   Statement I: Probability of drawing two blue balls from the bag is 1/6. Statement II: Probability of drawing a green ball from the bag is 1/4.
options: The data in statement I alone are sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement II alone are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement I alone are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data either in statement I alone or in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question.
The data given in both statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data in both statements I and II together are necessary to answer the question.

quiz.text: A bag contains certain number of black, pink and yellow balls. Numbers of pink balls in the bag are thrice the number of black balls in the bag which is equal to the number of yellow balls in the bag. Find the total number of balls in the bag.   Statement I: Two balls are randomly drawn from the bag. The probability that a black and a pink ball are drawn is 1/4. Statement II: The probability of drawing a yellow ball from the bag is 1/5.
options: The data in statement I alone are sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement II alone are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement I alone are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data either in statement I alone or in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question.
The data given in both statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data in both statements I and II together are necessary to answer the question.

quiz.text: A bag contains (x + 2) red, (x + 8) blue and (x – 4) grey balls. Find the number of grey balls in the bag.   Statement I: The probability of drawing a red ball from the bag is 1/3. Statement II: A blue ball is added to the bag and then two balls are randomly drawn from the bag. The probability that a red ball and a blue ball are drawn is 2/5.
options: The data in statement I alone are sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement II alone are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement I alone are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data either in statement I alone or in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question.
The data given in both statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data in both statements I and II together are necessary to answer the question.

quiz.text: A bag contains certain number of red, blue and green balls. Number of green balls in the bag is 25% less than the number of red balls in the bag which are 20% less than the number of blue balls in the bag. Find the total number of balls in the bag.   Statement I: Probability of drawing a green ball from the bag is 1/4. Statement II: Probability of drawing two blue balls from the bag is 1/6.
options: The data in statement I alone are sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement II alone are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement I alone are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data either in statement I alone or in statement II alone are sufficient to answer the question.
The data given in both statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question.
The data in both statements I and II together are necessary to answer the question.

quiz.text: There are three offices A, B and C and each office has some male employees and some female employees. The probability of selecting a female employee randomly from office A is 3/7, that from office B is 3/4 and that from office C is 2/5. If the ratio of the employees in office A, B and C is 7:8:10 respectively. Which of the following can be determined by using the above-given data? (i) The number of female employees in office B. (ii) Probability of selecting two male employees from office B. (iii) Total number of male employees in office A, B and C together. (iv) Ratio of the number of males employees in offices A, B and C respectively.
options: Only (ii)
Only (i), (ii) and (iv)
Only (i) and (ii)
Only (iv)
Only (iii)

quiz.text: A bag contains 6 red dices and ‘x’ yellow dices. The probability of choosing a yellow dice is 2/5. If two dices are drawn from the bag, then the probability of choosing a red dice and a yellow dice is ________.
options: 11/18
8/17
2/5
7/15
None of these

quiz.text: A bag contains 4 red, 3 blue and 2 green stones. 3 stones are chosen at random. The probability that at least 2 stones chosen will be blue is _______.
options: 19/84
7/24
1/9
3/14
None of these

quiz.text: A box contains (x – 3) red, (x – 4) green and (x – 1) blue balls. If the probability of getting a red and a green ball from the bag is 1/6, then find the value of ‘x’.
options: 3
8
12
6
None of these

quiz.text: A panel has 12 men and 9 women. Three persons are to be selected from the panel for a management committee. The number of ways a management committee can be formed such that at least 2 men are there in the committee is _________.
options: 814 ways
916 ways
856 ways
726 ways
None of these

quiz.text: A bag contains 8 blue balls, 7 green and 6 red balls. Two balls are randomly drawn from the bag. The probability that a green and a red ball are drawn is _______
options: 1/5
2/5
1/10
3/10
None of these
